Author: Deege
Title: Works great but not as quickly as the videos
Body: This gadget is really controversial -- people like it or they hate it. I like it. But it IS really over-hyped.Pros*It mostly works. I've had no problem shredding freshly cooked chicken. It does a lousy job at cold chicken and isn't designed for raw meat at all.*It stays where I put it on my granite countertop if I press hard enough to shred the chicken. The one place where it slipped on an uneven surface, I just put it on a silicone trivet.*I haven't had any plastic blades break off (yet) on either of these that I've bought for house and guest apartment. It's too expensive for a kitchen gadget for it to be disposable but it won't work well if a blade breaks off and I'd hate to serve broken plastic.*I don't precut my chicken breast after cooking. I just throw it in the shredder, put the lid on, and give it a few twists to get it started. A thick breast sinks down pretty quickly, after which I go back and forth and round and round. But this where some people get frustrated. I usually have to stop, pull the the unshredded chicken piece out, flip, and place it back in the shredder off-center and shred some more. For me, it's still faster than forks or Bear Paw shredders.Cons*Having to stop to flip the meat. Not the biggest problem but adds a step.*Clean up can be a pain. I scrape as much meat out as I can then rinse the residue into the garbage disposer. I don't lose much chicken but it's not nearly zero like I get with forks or Bear Paws. Then I wash in the dishwasher, top rack only. It's always been OK in the dishwasher. I would not use the shredder without a dishwasher -- too hard to clean.*The biggest complaint I have (and I knew it was coming) is the one a lot of people have: storage. It's as big and thick as a medium skillet and isn't easy to store in a small-ish kitchen. It might be impossible to store in an efficiency kitchen.
